Scheme 1 Procedure for preparing Cu@GLA-PEI-CA hydrogel beads. Scheme 1 Scheme 2 Flowchart of dynamic catalytic experiment using hydrogel beads as catalysts. Scheme 2 Fig. 1 FT-IR spectra of CA-1, PEI-CA-1 and GLA-PEI-CA-1 beads. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 XRD patterns of Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-1 (a) and Cu@C-700 beads (b). Fig. 2 Fig. 3 N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms (a) and pore size distribution curves of the beads after freeze-drying process. Graphical abstract A hard template-induced internal solidification strategy was developed to prepare a hydrogel bead-supported catalyst with ultrafine Cu NPs, high specific surface area and well-developed hierarchical pore structure, which exhibited remarkably catalytic activity and high stability. The development of a sustainable catalyst with high catalytic activity and easy recovery property is an important subject in the field of heterogeneous catalysis. In this work, we developed a hard template-induced internal solidification procedure for preparation of ultrafine metal nanoparticles (NPs) supported on GLA-PEI-CA beads. During the fabrication process, CaCO3 NPs had a dual function, not only serviced as a hard template to adjust the structure of the as-prepared catalyst, but also as an indirect crosslinking agent to obtain hydrogel beads. The resulting beads were characterized using FT-IR, XRD, BET, SEM, TEM, EDS and XPS. The results revealed that Cu NPs with a narrow size distribution in 2–3 nm were uniformly immobilized on the surface of GLA-PEI-CA-1 beads with high specific surface area and well-developed hierarchical pore structure. As a result, the Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-1 beads exhibited remarkably catalytic activity and high stability, with more than 90% conversion within 10 successive cycles, towards the reduction of 4-nitrophenol (4-NP) to 4-aminophenol (4-AP) by NaBH4 in aqueous solution. The result showed that the Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-1 catalyst displayed high kinetic responses with a kinetic reaction rate constant of 1.60 × 10−2 s−1, which was higher than that of Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-0 (without CaCO3 template) and Cu@GLA-CA-1 (without PEI coating). The enhanced catalytic performance was resulted from homogeneous distribution of Cu NPs along with the tailored microstructure and the hydrophilic surface of the support. Additionally, the dynamic catalytic experiment was conducted to investigate the catalytic performance of Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-1 beads as the catalyst. We expected that this work could provide a new and effective strategy to design highly efficient catalysts for various catalytic reactions. Keywords Hard template Internal solidification Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-1 beads Enhanced catalytic activity 1 Introduction Organic pollutants are widely generated as by-products of the industrial and agricultural sectors, such as organic colorants, organic pigments, pesticides and pharmaceutical products [1]. These pollutants can exist stably in water, which greatly damages human health and the sustainable development of human society [2]. The Unites States Environmental Protection Agency has listed NP as hazardous wastes and priority toxic pollutants. The maximum allowable concentration of NP in surface water is 0.02 mg L−1 [3]. Up to now, various methods have been mentioned for dealing with organic pollutants, including extraction, adsorption and catalytic degradation [4,5]. Among them, the catalytic degradation is considered as a convenient and efficient method for removal of organic pollutants in water. Therefore, it is necessary to explore a catalyst that can effectively deal with pollutants in a water medium. In recent years, metal-based composite NPs are found to have widely applications in various fields, such as electrocatalysis [6], energy storage device [7], catalysis [8], battery [9], as well as supercapacitor [10]. Among them, metal NPs have received considerable attention due to their excellent and durable activity as heterogeneous catalysts in many liquid-phase catalytic reactions [11–15]. Particularly, non-noble metal-based catalysts, including Cu, Ni, Fe, and Co, have attracted much more interest due to their low cost and potential industrial applications [16–19]. According to the previously reported work in the field of catalysis, the distribution, morphology and size of metal NPs have an important influence on their own catalytic activity during the catalytic process [20–22]. Generally speaking, the reduction of metal particle size results in an increase of catalytic activity [23]. Unfortunately, metal NPs are easy to aggregate and grow into larger particles during the catalytic reaction because of their large surface area and high surface energy, which results in a significant reduction in the catalytic activity and limits the lifetime of catalysts [24]. In order to avoid the formation of aggregation, ultrafine metal NPs are usually synthesized in the presence of various surfactants and stabilizing polymers. However, the strong coordination between additives and metal NPs will cause a partial loss of the catalytic activity. Moreover, it is quite difficult to recycle metal NPs, especially for the surfactant-protected metal NPs. To address these issues, metal NPs are usually immobilized on solid supports with high surface area and well-developed porosity. An ideal support for metal NPs requires a high surface area to volume ratio to provide more active sites [25], a hierarchical porous structure to shorten the mass transfer distance of reactants [26], a surface with large number of functional groups to couple with small sized NPs, an excellent chemical stability to maintain its structure, as well as a monolithic structure to improve the recycling ability during the reaction process. Among them, mesoporous SiO2, zeolite and porous Al2O3 are commonly acted as supports for loading metal NPs [27–29]. However, it requires expensive soft template to prepare these porous materials. In addition to silica-based supports, carbon-based materials, such as activated carbon [30], porous carbon [31], carbon nanotube [32] and graphene [33] have been proved to be a popular candidate to load metal NPs due to their high stability in the acidic and alkaline solutions. However, the carbon-based supports exhibit a strong hydrophobic property, which is not benefit for the catalytic reaction in water environment. Therefore, the development of new porous materials for embedding metal NPs is in high demand for various catalytic reactions. More recently, biomass materials have been widely employed as supports for metal NPs in view of their integrated advantages of low cost, hydrophilic property and easy functionalization. As an example of such a development, Qi et al. [34] reported a simple seed mediated strategy to prepare starch supported catalyst with enriched Au NPs, which exhibited superior catalytic performance for the degradation of organic pollutants. Also, Mezzetta et al. [35] successfully supported silver NPs on a chitosan-based polymer matrix. The catalyst displayed excellent catalytic activity towards a series of catalytic reactions. It is known that sodium alginate is a kind of biomass material extracted from brown algae, which contains a lot of functional groups. Upon the addition of divalent ions, the corresponding alginate hydrogel could be readily formed. As such hydrogel possesses the integrated features of environmental sustainability, high porosity, high surface area and easy surface modification, there is an increasing interest in the use of alginate-based hydrogels as supports for metal NPs. In our earlier reported work, alginate-based hydrogel supported catalyst with Ag NPs was prepared. The catalyst displayed durable and high catalytic activity towards 4-NP to 4-AP [36]. However, the as-prepared catalyst exhibited a broad size distribution and the surface area was still relatively low. Therefore, the rational design and fabrication of catalysts with higher surface area and well-dispersed metal NPs is more meaningful for catalysis applications. It is well accepted that the structure of the supported materials can be adjusted effectively with the assistance of hard templates, such as SiO2 beads [37], polymeric spheres [38], as well as CaCO3 NPs [39]. In our opinion, CaCO3 NPs are preferred to employ as hard template to fabricate porous materials, because it has the advantages of easy removal, high safety and good recyclable ability. Take the above discussions into consideration, it is probable to use CaCO3 NPs as a template to fabricate an alginate hydrogel-based catalyst with typical hierarchical porous structure, high surface area, as well as excellent accessibility with active sites, which enhances the catalytic activity in water-medium reactions. In the present study, we presented a hard template-induced internal solidification approach to fabricate ultrafine Cu NPs immobilized on GLA-PEI-CA-1 beads using CaCO3 NPs as hard template and curing agent, PEI as a surface modification regent. The as-prepared beads provided high surface area, developed porosity, 3D interconnected honeycomb-like porous structure, as well as homogeneous distribution of metal NPs. The catalytic performances of Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-1 beads, Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-0 and Cu@GLA-CA-1 beads for the reduction of 4-NP to 4-AP in the presence of NaBH4 aqueous solution were studied. As we expected, the Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-1 beads exhibited the highest catalytic activity and excellent recyclability. Moreover, the dynamic catalysis result showed that the Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-1 beads also displayed higher catalytic activity than that of Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-0 and Cu@GLA-CA-1 beads. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Copper nitrate trihydrate (Cu (NO3)2·3H2O), nickel chloride hexahydrate (NiCl2·6H2O), silver nitrate (AgNO3) and calcium carbonate (CaCO3, average size: 800 nm) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd, China. Sodium borohydride (NaBH4), polyethyleneimine (molecular weight: 600), Tri-hydroxymethyl aminomethane and 4-NP were obtained from Aladdin Chemistry Co., Ltd, China. Glutaraldehyde solution (GLA, 50 wt%), HCl (36–38 wt%) and ethanol (CH3CH2OH, minimum 99.9 wt%) were provided from Tianjin Guangfu Chemical Research Institute, China. Biscyclohexanone oxalyldihydrazone was purchased from Shanghai Mai Kun Chemical Co., Ltd. All chemicals were of analytical grade and used without further purification. Deionized water was used throughout the experiment. 2.2 Synthesis of CA beads In a typical synthesis, the mixture containing a certain amount of CaCO3 NPs and sodium alginate (1 g) was firstly dispersed in deionized water (50 mL). Next, the as-prepared mixture was added dropwise to a HCl solution (0.05 M, 400 mL) under continuous magnetic stirring condition. Immediately, calcium alginate hydrogel beads containing CaCO3 NPs were obtained. After CaCO3 template was fully reacted with hydrochloric acid, the obtained beads were stirred in a fresh CaCl2 solution (5 wt%, 50 mL) for 12 h to achieve complete solidification. Afterwards, the samples were thoroughly washed with deionized water for 3 times to remove an excess of Ca2+ and Cl− ions. Lastly, the beads were collected for further use. The obtained calcium alginate beads with a certain amount of CaCO3 NPs were denoted as CA-X, where X represented the quality of CaCO3 NPs. It should be pointed that the CA-0 beads were prepared by directly adding the solution of sodium alginate without CaCO3 NPs into a CaCl2 solution. 2.3 Cu@GLA-PEI-CA beads Briefly, the as-prepared CA beads were then added into a solution of PEI (0.2 g) in water (50 mL). After stirring for 12 h, the samples were washed with deionized water for 3 times. Subsequently, the as-prepared PEI-CA beads were chemically cross linked with a GLA solution (50 wt%, 2 mL) at 50 °C under magnetic stirring for 2 h. The GLA-PEI-CA beads were washed repeatedly with deionized water. Next, the resulted beads were introduced into a Cu (NO3)2 solution (0.3 g, 100 mL). After stirring for 12 h, the hydrogel beads were separated and washed with deionized water for 3 times. Then, NaBH4 (0.076 g) was added into the suspension containing the beads under magnetic stirring, and the synthesis system was allowed to react for 12 h. Immediately, Cu ions absorbed on the hydrogel beads were reduced to Cu NPs. In the end, Cu@GLA-PEI-CA beads were successfully prepared. For comparison, Cu@GLA-CA beads without PEI modification were synthesized using a similar procedure. In order to prove the existence of Cu NPs, Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-1 beads were heated to 700 °C by N2 protection, and the obtained samples were recorded as Cu@C-700. 2.4 Structural characterization CA, PEI-CA and GLA-PEI-CA beads were characterized using FTIR (IR-960 spectrometer, China) in the wavenumber range of 400–4000 cm−1. The structure and surface morphology of the samples (Cu@GLA-CA-1, Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-0 and Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-1 beads) were observed by a field emission-scanning electron microscope (FESEM, JEM JEOL 2100) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, Hitachi H9000NAR). The surface composition of the samples was analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo ESCA LAB 250). X-ray diffraction (XRD) data of the Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-1 and Cu@C-700 beads were recorded in the 2θ range of 10–80°. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were measured at 77 K using JW-BK222 analyzer. Specific surface areas were calculated by a Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method and the pore size distributions were acquired using a Barret-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) model. 2.5 Cu2+ ions analysis The Cu2+ ions concentration was determined by a colorimetric method. Briefly, Tri-hydroxymethyl aminomethane (2 mL, 0.1 mol L−1) was added into a solution containing a certain amount of Cu2+ ions (5.8 mL). Afterwards, biscyclohexanone oxalyldihydrazone (1.2 mL, 1 wt%) was mixed into the above solution to form blue complexes composed. UV–vis spectrophotometer was used to analyze the absorbance of the solution at wavelength of 600 nm. According to the standard curve made by the blue complex, the Cu2+ ions concentration in the solution was calculated. 2.6 Cu2+ ions adsorption experiment Adsorption kinetics experiments were performed by adding hydrogel beads into a solution of Cu (NO3)2. Cu2+ ions solution (100 mg L−1, 20 mL) was put into a 100 mL glass conical flask at 25 °C. Then, the beads (20 mg) were added into the above solution. The concentration of Cu2+ ions in the solution was analyzed at different time interval by a UV–vis spectroscopy until reaching the adsorption equilibrium. 2.7 Catalytic activities of Cu@GLA-CA-1, Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-0 and Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-1 beads Typically, the beads (2 mg) were added into an aqueous solution with 4-NP (2.5 mM) and NaBH4 (15 mM) in water (20 mL). At intervals of 30 s, the residual concentration of 4-NP in the solution was measured by UV–vis spectroscopy at wavelength of 400 nm. 2.8 Dynamic catalytic experiment Dynamic catalytic experiment was conducted in a laboratory glass column, as shown in Scheme 2. Briefly, the as-prepared beads (0.5 g) were tightly packed in a glass column with an internal diameter of 1.0 cm and a length of 10 cm. At both sides of the column, the degreasing cotton was inserted to fix the catalyst. Afterwards, the wastewater containing 4-NP (2.5 mM) and NaBH4 (15 mM) was pumped into the fixed-bed column at a flow rate of 1 mL min−1. The reaction product was collected at a regular interval and the residual concentration of 4-NP was tested by UV–vis spectroscopy. 3 Results and discussion Scheme 1 presents the hard template-induced internal solidification approach for preparing Cu@GLA-PEI-CA hydrogel beads. Typically, the solution of sodium alginate contains a certain amount of CaCO3 NPs is added dropwise into a HCl aqueous solution. The reaction takes place between CaCO3 and HCl at once. The resulted Ca2+ ions lead to the formation of CA hydrogel beads by forming an egg-box structure. Simultaneously, the removal of CaCO3 NPs by HCl etching creates a lot of voids in the beads. Upon the addition of CA beads into PEI solution, PEI is grafted on the surface of CA beads via the interaction between the positively charged amine groups and the negatively charged carboxylate groups. In order to enhance the interaction between them, GLA is used as a crosslinking agent to react with PEI and CA. After that, Cu2+ ions were adsorbed on the surface of PEI-CA beads through the complexation between Cu2+ ions and amine groups. Then, the Cu2+ ions are reduced into Cu NPs by NaBH4. At last, the Cu@GLA-PEI-CA beads are successfully fabricated. FT-IR is widely used to investigate the functional groups of the samples. FT-IR spectra of CA-1, PEI-CA-1 and GLA-PEI-CA-1 beads are given in Fig. 1 . It can be seen that the three spectra display a strong similarity in the main characteristic FT-IR bands. For CA-1 beads, the spectrum contains a strong absorption peak at 3343 cm−1, which corresponds to the stretching vibration of OH group. The weak peak at around 2929 cm−1is caused by the stretching band of CH group. The sharp peaks at 1600 and 1426 cm−1 are attributed to the symmetric and asymmetric skeletal stretching vibrations of CO group, respectively. After PEI grafted on the CA-1 surface, the OH and NH stretching vibration peaks are clearly shifted to 3400 cm−1 and broader than that of CA-1 beads. Furthermore, a new and weak peak at the position of 2852 cm−1 is clearly observed, which is caused by the stretching vibrations of CH and CH2 groups. It has been reported in our previous work that the CA beads could be crosslinked with GLA, which can effectively enhance their structural stability during the catalytic reaction. Herein, GLA solution is also selected as a crosslinking agent to enhance the chemical and mechanical properties of PEI-CA-1 hydrogel beads. Although the spectrum of PEI-CA-1 hydrogel beads crosslinked with GLA displays no obvious change in the characteristic FT-IR bands compared with the spectrum of PEI-CA-1 beads, the color of the beads changes from white to brown after crosslinking, as shown in Fig. S1. The results confirm that the chemical crosslinking between GLA and PEI-CA-1 was carried out. The chemical structure of Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-1 beads and Cu@C-700 was characterized by XRD. XRD pattern in Fig. 2 a exhibits two obvious broad peaks. The peaks located at 2θ = 25.5° is assigned to the characteristic peak of alginate, which indicates its amorphous nature. The wide peak at 2θ = 43.5° is probably indexed to be (111) of Cu NPs. The result reveals that the XRD pattern does not fit very well with the standard Cu NPs. This may be due to the low crystallinity of Cu NPs in the Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-1 beads. To verify the existence of Cu NPs, the Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-1 beads are heated at 700 °C under the protection of N2, the as-prepared sample is named as Cu@C-700. As shown in Fig. 2b, the characteristic diffraction peaks at around 2θ = 43.3°, 50.4° and 74.1° are corresponding to the characteristic peaks of Cu NPs, which are attributed to Cu (111), (200) and (220) in reference to JCPDS card No.85-1326. In addition, the peaks centered at 2θ = 23.5° in Cu@C-700 is assigned to the typical graphitic (002) plane of carbonous material. It is well known that the structural properties of catalysts have an important effect on their catalytic performance. In this work, the catalytic activities of the hydrogel beads as catalysts are investigated. In order to maintain the original structure of the hydrogel beads a freeze-drying technique is employed to dry the hydrogel beads rather than drying in the oven. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distribution curves of the samples are shown in Fig. 3 a and b, respectively. The specific surface area, pore volume and average pore size are listed in Table 1 . As shown in Fig. 3a, all the adsorption-desorption isotherms are of type Ⅳ. The shape rises at high relative pressure from 0.9 to 1 (P/P0) indicate that lots of large mesopores and macropores are generated during the freeze-drying process. The hydrogel beads have nearly similar hierarchical porous structure. By comparison, Cu@GLA-CA-1 beads (110 m2 g−1) clearly show a lower surface area than Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-1 beads (139 m2 g−1), which proves that PEI coating and chemical crosslinking by GLA induces the formation of more pores, which is well coincided with the SEM images. As expected, the specific surface areas of the Cu@GLA-PEI-CA beads become higher with the increasing amount of CaCO3 NPs. However, the surface area of Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-2 (113 m2 g−1) is lower than that of Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-1 beads (139 m2 g−1), which may be due to the collapse of pores during the solidification process. It should be pointed out that the pore volume of Cu@GLA-CA-1 (0.29 cm3 g−1) is smaller than that of Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-1 (0.51 cm3 g−1). It is due to the fact that Cu@GLA-CA-1 beads show a stronger shrinkage after the freeze-drying process. According the above N2 adsorption-desorption data, PEI coating strongly affects the structure of the samples. SEM analysis provides more information about the surface morphology and internal structure. As shown from SEM images in Fig. 4 a, Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-0 beads have a large number of macropores, which is in the size range of a few nanometers to several hundred nanometers (<500 nm). For further probe into the influence of CaCO3 NPs on the internal structure, Cu@GLA-CA-1 and Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-1 beads are prepared and characterized, as illustrated in Fig. 4b and c. Both Cu@GLA-CA-1 and Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-1 beads clearly display a typical three-dimensional interconnected honeycomb-like porous structure. The pores are much larger than that of Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-0, which is resulted from the removal of CaCO3. By comparing Fig. 4b with 4c, it can be confirmed that PEI coating on the CA-1 beads gives rise to plenty of small pores on the basis of the original network and makes the framework to be rough. As a result, the Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-1 beads exhibit more developed porosity and larger specific surface area. In addition, it is difficult to observe Cu NPs from the SEM images, which indicates that the size of Cu NPs is quite small. To prove this point, the morphology and the size of Cu NPs are measured with TEM. TEM image of Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-0 beads are shown in Fig. 4d. Cu NPs with a narrow size distribution are uniformly immobilized on the surface of the hydrogel beads. And the average diameter of the Cu NPs is about 2.5 nm. Therefore, these ultrafine Cu NPs are expected to exhibit high catalytic activity during the catalytic reaction. In contrast, the Cu@GLA-CA-1 beads show uneven distribution of Cu particles, whose size is in the range of 9.5–15.5 nm, as shown in Fig. 4e. Fig. 4f displays the TEM image of Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-1 beads. It can be clearly observed that the size and dosage of Cu NPs on the beads are almost same, which suggests that the introduction of PEI on the beads can effectively restrict the growth of Cu NPs. According to N2 adsorption-desorption data, the specific surface area of the as-prepared material can be greatly increased by removing CaCO3 hard template. Thus, the Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-1 beads will provide more active sites to enhance the catalytic activity. Besides, EDS analysis is conducted to obtain the detail element distribution, which is shown in Fig. 4g, h, i, m and n. The EDS mapping of the Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-1 beads demonstrates the existing of Ca, N and Cu. It should be noted that the EDS mapping of Cu element is almost similar with that of N element, which strongly proves that PEI grafting on the surface of CA beads dominates the distribution of Cu NPs. In order to further analyze the composition and existence of elements, the XPS characterizations of Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-1, Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-0 and Cu@GLA-CA-1 beads were performed, respectively. As illustrated in Fig. 5 a, the appearance of a new peak at the bonding energy of 397 eV, which is related to N1s peak, verified that PEI is coated on the surface of the beads by comparison of full-range XPS spectrum of Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-1with that of Cu@GLA-CA-1. The characterized peaks at binding energies of about 284, 530, 354 and 962 eV in all samples are ascribed to C1s, O1s, Ca2p and Cu2p, respectively. The XPS spectra for Cu 2p in Cu@GLA-CA-1 and Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-1 beads are shown in Fig. 5b and c. The high-resolution spectrum of Cu 2p XPS signals at 947–955 eV and 927–935 eV are known from the Cu 2p1/2 and Cu 2p3/2, respectively (Fig. 5b). The deconvoluted Cu 2p3/2 peak reveals two components at 932.4 and 929.8 eV, ascribing to the binding energy of zero-valence states of Cu. And the peak at 951.1 eV is assigned to Cu 2p1/2. In addition, Fig. 5c shows a new peak at 942.6 eV can be attributed to N-coordinated Cu NPs. As well as the satellites peak further confirmed the formation of pure metallic Cu NPs. According to the XPS results, the atoms content of C, O, N and Cu can be calculated, as listed in Table 2 . It can be found that the Cu content in Cu@GLA-CA-1, Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-0 and Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-1 beads is increased as the N content is improved, suggesting that the existing of amine group is strongly favor for the adsorption of Cu2+ ions. The contents of Cu, C, O and N in Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-1 beads are 1.11 at%, 64.57 at%, 27.63 at% and 6.36 at%. It can be calculated that the Cu loading amount is around 6.11 wt%. In addition, the effects of different supporting materials on the adsorption of Cu2+ ions are further investigated to calculate the Cu loading amount. Fig. 5d shows the effect of contact time on the Cu2+ ions adsorption onto the GLA-PEI-CA-1, GLA-PEI-CA-0 and GLA-CA-1 hydrogel beads at the same initial concentration. The rapid adsorption at the initial stage can be attributed to a large number of amine groups or oxygen-containing functional groups that stay on the beads. As the adsorption time is increased, the adsorption sites on the beads are remarkably covered by Cu2+ ions, which results in adsorption slowing until an adsorption equilibrium is reached. When the reaction time is maintained for 100 min, the adsorption amount towards Cu2+ ions is 45 mg g−1 (GLA-PEI-CA-1), 30 mg g−1 (GLA-PEI-CA-0) and 25 mg g−1 (GLA-CA-1). The results show that both surface property (PEI coating) and textual characteristic (removal of hard template) of the supporting material have an important influence on the Cu2+ ions adsorption behavior. The adsorption capacity of Cu2+ ions is 64 mg g−1 for GLA-PEI-CA-1 hydrogel beads, which is well agreement with the Cu loading amount calculated by XPS data. To demonstrate the catalytic activity of the samples, the reduction of 4-NP to 4-AP is selected as a model reaction to evaluate their catalytic performance. As shown in Fig. 6 a, the 4-NP solution displays an absorption peak at 318 nm in UV–vis spectrum. With the addition of NaBH4, the characteristic peak shifts to 400 nm and the color of the solution changes from light yellow to bright yellow. When the Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-1 beads is introduced into the solution, the peak at 400 nm decreases slowly and a new peak appears at 300 nm. This new peak corresponds to 4-AP in Fig. 6b. The Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-1 beads exhibit high catalytic activity and the reduction of 4-NP is completed within 180 s. For Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-0 beads, Fig. 6c shows that 4-NP is completely converted to 4-AP within 280 s. Compared with Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-1 and Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-0 beads, Cu@GLA-CA-1 beads exhibit the diminished catalytic activity. And the reduction of 4-NP is completed within 33 min, 30 min longer than that of Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-1 beads, as shown in Fig. 6d. It means that PEI introduction on the beads allows the formation of the catalyst with ultrafine Cu NPs, which can provide much more catalytic active sites towards the reduction of 4-NP. Fig. 6e shows a linear relationship between ln(C/C0) and reaction time in the reduction of 4-NP to 4-AP using different catalysts. The reaction follows a first-order law and the kinetic equation can be written as: ln(C/C0) =-kt. The value of k is kinetic rate constant. It can be calculated that k value is 1.60 × 10−2 s-1 (Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-1), 8.56 × 10-3 s-1 (Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-0) and 1.89 × 10-3 s-1 (Cu@GLA-CA-1), respectively. Among them, the recyclability of the Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-1 beads as the catalyst is studied. It can be found that about 10% loss in the conversion is observed after the beads are recycled for 10 times, which proves that the catalyst possesses durable activity. As shown in Fig. S2a, it can be seen that about 20% loss in the conversion is observed after the Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-0 beads are reused for 9 times. For Cu@GLA-CA-1 beads, the reduction efficiency still kept above 72.5% after 10 recycling experiments (Fig. S2b). By comparison, Cu NPs were stably immobilized on the surface of GLA-PEI-CA-1 beads due to the strong interaction between Cu NPs and amine groups. Therefore, the Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-1 beads exhibit better reusability. Moreover, we make a comparison of the catalytic activity of Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-1 beads with other catalysts, as shown in Table 3 . These catalysts display higher catalytic activity. In particularly, kinetic rate constant of the Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-1 beads are as high as 1.60 × 10−2 s−1. It is well known that dynamic catalytic experiment simulates the application of catalysts in actual industrial production. Fig. 6g, h and i show the relationship between the residual concentration and reaction time at a same flow rate of 1 mL min-1. For Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-1 beads, the minimum residual concentration of 0.391 mg L−1 can be achieved when the reaction is maintained for 25 min. And the corresponding residual concentrations for Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-0 and Cu@GLA-CA-1 beads reach to 1.314 and 3.619 mg L−1, respectively. The results are consistent with the previous batch condition. In order to find out whether the method is suitable for other metal nanoparticle-supported catalysts, we have designed a series of experiments to prepare Ag@GLA-PEI-CA-1 and Ni@GLA-PEI-CA-1 beads by replacing Cu (NO3)2 with AgNO3 and NiCl2 during the synthetic process. As shown in Fig. S3a, a large amount of Ag NPs with an average size of 3.25 nm is uniformly dispersed on Ag@GLA-PEI-CA-1 beads. The TEM image in Fig. S3b clearly shows that Ni NPs are also well distributed in the beads and their size can be controlled in the range of 3.51–4.75 nm. As a result, both Ag@GLA-PEI-CA-1 and Ni@GLA-PEI-CA-1 catalysts show excellent catalytic performance towards the reduction of 4-NP to 4-AP (Fig. S4). These results further prove that the presented method can be widely applied to fabricate other highly efficient and cost-effective catalysts for various catalytic reactions. 4 Conclusions In summary, a hard template-induced internal solidification technique was developed to fabricate highly efficient catalysts for the reduction of 4-NP. During the synthetic process, the CA hydrogel beads with 3D interconnected and honeycomb-like porous structure and high surface area were obtained using CaCO3 NPs as a hard template and an indirect crosslinking agent. By coating PEI on the CA beads, which containing a large amount of amine groups, ultrafine Cu NPs (∼2.5 nm) were uniformly and tightly deposited on the GLA-PEI-CA-1 beads. The as-prepared Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-1 beads exhibited excellent catalytic activity and good reusability, beyond 90% conversion within 10 cycles, for 4-NP to 4-AP in NaBH4 aqueous solution. Also, the dynastic catalytic experiments of Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-1, Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-0 and Cu@GLA-CA-1 beads as catalysts were performed. The results indicated that the microstructure of supports, the size and distribution of metal NPs have an important influence on the catalytic activity during the reaction. This work demonstrated that a rational design of a catalyst can effectively enhance the catalytic performance. Conflicts of interest There are no conflicts to declare. coredata.dc:description: The development of a sustainable catalyst with high catalytic activity and easy recovery property is an important subject in the field of heterogeneous catalysis. In this work, we developed a hard template-induced internal solidification procedure for preparation of ultrafine metal nanoparticles (NPs) supported on GLA-PEI-CA beads. During the fabrication process, CaCO3 NPs had a dual function, not only serviced as a hard template to adjust the structure of the as-prepared catalyst, but also as an indirect crosslinking agent to obtain hydrogel beads. The resulting beads were characterized using FT-IR, XRD, BET, SEM, TEM, EDS and XPS. The results revealed that Cu NPs with a narrow size distribution in 2–3 nm were uniformly immobilized on the surface of GLA-PEI-CA-1 beads with high specific surface area and well-developed hierarchical pore structure. As a result, the Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-1 beads exhibited remarkably catalytic activity and high stability, with more than 90% conversion within 10 successive cycles, towards the reduction of 4-nitrophenol (4-NP) to 4-aminophenol (4-AP) by NaBH4 in aqueous solution. The result showed that the Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-1 catalyst displayed high kinetic responses with a kinetic reaction rate constant of 1.60 × 10−2 s−1, which was higher than that of Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-0 (without CaCO3 template) and Cu@GLA-CA-1 (without PEI coating). The enhanced catalytic performance was resulted from homogeneous distribution of Cu NPs along with the tailored microstructure and the hydrophilic surface of the support. Additionally, the dynamic catalytic experiment was conducted to investigate the catalytic performance of Cu@GLA-PEI-CA-1 beads as the catalyst. We expected that this work could provide a new and effective strategy to design highly efficient catalysts for various catalytic reactions.
coredata.dc:title: Hard template-induced internal solidification synthesis of Cu NPs- supported glutaraldehyde-crosslinked polyethyleneimine-modified calcium alginate beads with enhanced catalytic activity
